page.title: Stabbing of Adele Morales by Norman Mailer

revision.text:
During a November 1960 party celebrating his mayoral candidacy, American public intellectual [[Norman Mailer]] twice stabbed his wife [[Adele Morales]] with a pen-knife in a drunken altercation, nearly taking her life. The incident, though by many accounts swept under the rug by Mailer and his associates, had a lasting impact on his public and critical legacy and persona.
== Incident == On the night of November 19, 1960, Mailer and his wife Adele Morales hosted a party, intended to launch his proposed New York mayoral campaign, at the Upper West Side apartment the couple shared with their two young daughters. Mailer had enlisted his well-connected friend, journalist [[George Plimpton]], to attract figures from the city's "power structure", he hoped to unite at his party this elite echelon with the "disenfranchised" population he saw as his natural constituency—having written of the "courage" of hoodlums in his 1957 essay "[[The White Negro]]"—into a voting base that would propel him to office.<ref name=hughes2012>Evan Hughes. [http://nymag.com/news/features/scandals/norman-mailer-2012-4/ "Norman Mailer Runs For Mayor, Stabs Wife"]. ''NYMag.com''. 12 April 2012. Retrieved March 30, 2017.</ref>
Though [[David Rockefeller]] and the [[Aga Khan IV|Aga Khan]] declined the invitation, the party's approximately two hundred guests included the poet [[Allen Ginsberg]], as well as several "derelicts, cut-throats and bohemians"—many of them homeless—whom Mailer had recruited off the street.<ref name=grimes2015>William Grimes. [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/24/arts/adele-mailer-artist-who-married-norman-mailer-dies-at-90.html" Adele Mailer, Artist Who Married Norman Mailer, Dies at 90"]. ''New York Times'', November 23, 2015, accessed April 20, 2016.</ref><ref name=hughes2012 /> This produced an atmosphere characterized by later commentators as at best, "legendarily tetchy" and at worst, "the most dangerous evening I've ever spent in my life" (from publisher [[Barney Rosset]], a guest at the party).<ref name=dangerous>[http://dangerousminds.net/comments/norman_mailer_stabbing_your_wife_as_an_existential_experiment "Norman Mailer: Stabbing Your Wife as an Existential Experiment"]. ''dangerous minds.net'', June 1, 2013. Retrieved March 30, 2017.</ref><ref name=video2010>[http://www.normanmailertheamerican.com ''Norman Mailer: The American'']. Joseph Mantega. Cinema Libre Studio, 2010. Video.</ref>
Fights broke out throughout the course of the night and tensions ran high—by some accounts, Norman Mailer at one point divided guests "on opposite sides of the room according to whether he considered them 'for' or 'against' him"—with a near-incoherent Mailer eventually leaving the apartment to seek trouble elsewhere. Morales later recalled that "he was down in the street punching people….He didn't know what his name was, he was so out of it".<ref name=video2010 /><ref name=dangerous />
When Mailer returned at 4:30 a.m. to find all of the guests departed but for the "five or six" who remained in the dining room and Morales getting ready for bed, the altercation broke out. The enraged Mailer burst into the room and Morales taunted his heterosexual masculinity and made a disparaging reference to his mistress.<ref name=hughes2012 /><ref name=video2010 /> Mailer rushed at her, stabbing her with a rusty two-and-a-half inch penknife, once in the back and once through her breast, puncturing her cardiac sac and narrowly missing her heart. Mailer addressed the shocked guests standing over Morales' prostrate body, saying "Don't touch her. Let the bitch die".<ref name=video2010 /> Morales was rushed downstairs to the apartment of novelist Doc Hume and from there in a taxi cab to University Hospital for emergency surgery.<ref name=manso1985>Peter Manso. ''Mailer: His Life and Times'' (New York: Washington Square Press, 1985), 331. {{ISBN|978-1-4165-6286-3}}</ref>
==Aftermath== While she remained in critical condition, Morales initially told doctors that she "had fallen on some glass", denying any wrongdoing on the part of Mailer, who had come to the hospital later that night to "lecture Adele's surgeon on the likely dimensions of her wound".<ref name=manso1985 /> Mailer appeared the next day in a scheduled interview on ''The Mike Wallace Show'', where he spoke of the knife as a symbol of manhood and continued to plug his mayoral bid.<ref name=dangerous />
Two days later, in the hospital's intensive care unit, Morales admitted to police that Mailer had stabbed her; he was arrested at the hospital and involuntarily committed for seventeen days to Bellevue Hospital for psychiatric evaluation by a judge, who pronounced him "both homicidal and suicidal".<ref name=grimes2015 /><ref name=harris2008>Mark Harris. [http://nymag.com/news/features/52176/ "Checkout Time at the Asylum"]. ''New York Magazine'', November 16, 2008. Retrieved March 30, 2017.</ref> Mailer maintained his sanity, responding "It is very important to me not to be sent to some mental institution. I'm a sane man. If this happens, for the rest of my life, my work will be considered as the work of a man with a disordered mind".<ref name=harris2008 />
Though Morales divorced him in 1962, she refused to press charges, citing a desire to protect their children.<ref name=trib2016>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-mailer-ex-wife-obit-20151123-story.html "Norman Mailer’s Ex-Wife Dead at 90, Found Fame as Stabbing Victim"]. ''Chicago Tribune'', November 23, 2015, accessed April 22, 2016. </ref> He was indicted by a grand jury on charges of felony assault but after pleading guilty to a reduced charge received probation and later a suspended sentence.<ref name=trib2016 />
==Public and critical reaction== The reaction to the incident in the literary community to which Mailer and Morales belonged has been judged by many observers to be remarkably mild. As Mailer later noted, his friends "closed ranks" behind him. He remarked to ''New York Magazine'' in 1983 that "the reactions were subtle as hell. Five degrees less warmth than I was accustomed to. Not fifteen degrees less—five."<ref>Marie Brenner. [https://normanmailer.us/mailer-goes-egyptian-d309d202da49 "Mailer Goes Egyptian"]. ''New York Magazine'', March 28, 1983: 32.</ref> Many of his counterparts saw the assault as an artistic, even literary act; [[James Baldwin]] a writer and friend of Mailer's, characterized it as an attempt to free himself from "the spiritual prison he had created with his fantasies of becoming a politician," "like burning down the house in order to, at last, be free of it".<ref>Louis Menand. [http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/10/21/the-norman-invasion The Norman Invasion: the Crazy Career of Norman Mailer"]. ''The New Yorker'', October 21, 2013. Retrieved March 30, 2017.</ref> [[Diana Trilling]] later recalled being told by her husband, critic [[Lionel Trilling]], that the stabbing was a "Dostoyevskian ploy" allowing Mailer to "test the limits of evil in himself."<ref name=manso1985 />
The attack was, according to many observers, entirely consistent with Mailer's public image, founded on bombastic machismo and an existentially tinged inclination toward norm-defying violence.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} The incident quickly became a focal point for criticism for Mailer's feminist contemporaries, particularly feminist writer [[Kate Millett]] in her 1970 work ''[[Sexual Politics]]'', who paralleled the attack with themes of sexual violence they found throughout his work.<ref>Kate Millett. ''Sexual Politics''. Garden City, NY: Doubleday, 1970. {{ISBN|978-0-2311-7425-1}}</ref> Nine years later Mailer launched a second mayoral campaign, received five percent of the votes cast and enjoyed the foundational support of prominent feminists [[Bella Abzug]] and [[Gloria Steinem]].<ref>Ginia Bellafante. [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/14/nyregion/a-question-of-forgiving.html "A Question of Forgiving"]. ''New York Times'', July 12, 2013, accessed April 21, 2016.</ref>
Mailer long remained publicly blasé about the assault. In 1971 he made a dismissive remark during his appearance on ''[[The Dick Cavett Show]]'', "We all know that I stabbed my wife many years ago. We all know that".<ref>"Norman Mailer vs. Gore Vidal." ''The Dick Cavett Show''. 15 December 1971. Television.</ref> Mailer's admission that the stabbing was "the one act I can look back on and regret for the rest of my life" in a 2000 interview, forty years after the fact, marked his first public expression of remorse.<ref> Michelle Dean. [http://flavorwire.com/420099/lets-be-clear-norman-mailers-wife-stabbing-was-not-art "Let’s Be Clear: Norman Mailer’s Wife-Stabbing Was Not Art."] ''Flavorwire'', October 14, 2013. Retrieved April 26, 2016.</ref>

{{refimprove|date=March 2010}} {{Infobox film | name = The Greatest | image = The Greatest poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical poster | director = [[Shana Feste]] | producer = [[Lynette Howell]]
[[Beau St. Clair]] | writer = Shana Feste | starring = [[Pierce Brosnan]]
[[Susan Sarandon]]
[[Carey Mulligan]] | music = [[Christophe Beck]] | cinematography = John Bailey | editing = Cara Silverman | studio = Barbarian Film Group
Oceana Media Finance
Silverwood Films
Irish DreamTime | released = {{Film date|2009|1|17|[[25th Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]]|2010|4|2|United States}} | runtime = 98 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $6 million | gross = $335,976 }} '''''The Greatest''''' is a 2009 American [[drama film]] written and directed by [[Shana Feste]] in her [[list of directorial debuts|directorial debut]], and starring [[Pierce Brosnan]] (also an executive producer), [[Susan Sarandon]], [[Carey Mulligan]], and [[Michael Shannon]]. ==Plot== Eighteen-year-old Bennett Brewer ([[Aaron Taylor-Johnson|Aaron Johnson]]) and Rose ([[Carey Mulligan|Mulligan]]) have sex together, the only time either of them have ever done so. When Bennett is killed when a truck crashes into his car while he is parked in the middle of the road at night, his family feel like they cannot go on. His mother Grace ([[Susan Sarandon|Sarandon]]) and his father Allen ([[Pierce Brosnan|Brosnan]]) get an unexpected visitor knocking at their door; it turns out to be Rose, who is pregnant with Bennett's child. As the story develops, Bennett's younger brother Ryan is introduced and he is grieving the fact he did not say a final good bye to his brother. One sees the true relationships of the family as the story comes together, Grace waits at the bed of Jordan Walker, the man driving the truck which collided with Bennett's car in the crash. She is waiting for him to wake so she can ask him what occurred during the 17 minutes between the crash and his death. After a while, she finds out the truth, but is disappointed with what she hears. In the last moments, Bennett was not calling for his mother - he was calling to Rose asking Walker to make sure that she was safe. Allen hires a cleaner to clean the house, but when Grace finds out she is terribly angry, claiming their son has been washed away. Allen then appears to be having a heart attack, whilst Grace carries on shouting until she realises what is happening. At the hospital bed, shortly after Grace returns from finding out about Bennett's final minutes, Allen breaks down crying, saying that he had been holding in all his grief and upset, and that he could have done something to prevent the crash and his son's death. Meanwhile, Rose has overheard Grace saying Rose should have died instead of Bennett, so she leaves and seeks the help of her own mother. She soon realises that all her mother is bothered about is trying to get money from the Brewers, claiming it will help her. The Brewers try to find Rose and they find her in labor and persuade her to go to the hospital and, while in the car on the way, she seeks to find out everything about Bennett she did not already know. When the film draws to a close, one sees Rose and the baby, a girl called Ruby, Grace's favourite girl's name. The film ends with the moment Bennett spoke to Rose earlier on the day he died. ==Production== Feste received the help of [[Creative Artists Agency]] (CAA) director Richard Lovett, for whom she had been working as an assistant in the past.{{cite web|last=Leydon|first=Joe|title=Shana Feste’s Nanny Diaries|url=http://www.moviemaker.com/articles-directing/shana-feste-country-strong-gwyneth-paltrow-20101201/|work=MovieMaker Magazine|accessdate=August 9, 2013|date=December 1, 2010}} The CAA sent [[Pierce Brosnan]]'s producing partner, [[Beau St. Clair]], the script and she convinced him to read it.{{cite web|last=Silverstein|first=Melissa|title=Interview with Shana Feste -- Writer and Director of The Greatest|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/melissa-silverstein/interview-with-shana-fest_b_523165.html|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=August 9, 2013|date=April 2, 2010}} Shortly after, [[Susan Sarandon]] joined the film, convinced by Brosnan.{{cite web|title=Susan Sarandon answers the call from Pierce Brosnan for 'The Greatest'|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/susan-sarandon-answers-call-pierce-brosnan-greatest-article-1.422820|publisher=NYDailyNews.com|accessdate=August 10, 2013|date=January 22, 2009}} Feste met with a lot of actresses for Carey Mulligan's role but ultimately Mulligan stood out. It was Feste's [[List of directorial debuts|directorial debut]]. To gain the confidence of investors and producers, she made a scrapbook which contained her ideas on tone, camera movement, color, space and lines. [[Principal photography]] took place in [[Rockland County, New York]]. The film was shot in [[35 mm film|35 mm format]].{{cite web|title=John Bailey, ASC: Exploring the aesthetics|url=http://motion.kodak.com/motion/uploadedFiles/johnBailey.pdf|publisher=Motion.kodak.com|accessdate=August 13, 2013}} ==Reception== The film screened at the [[2009 Sundance Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://defamer.gawker.com/5134316/is-the-greatest-destined-for-greatness|title=Is 'The Greatest' Destined For Greatness?|publisher=Gawker|accessdate=March 18, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100929174051/http://defamer.gawker.com/5134316/is-the-greatest-destined-for-greatness|archivedate=September 29, 2010|df=}} Another film starring Mulligan, the [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-nominated ''[[An Education]]'', also screened at the festival. The film ranking website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported that 52% of critics had given the film positive reviews, based upon a sample of 56.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1202111-greatest/ |title=The Greatest |accessdate=January 29, 2011 |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Flixster]]}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|1226232|The Greatest}} *{{allmovie|476956}} {{Shana Feste}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Greatest, The}} [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:2000s romantic drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American romantic drama films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about families]] [[Category:Films directed by Shana Feste]] [[Category:Films scored by Christophe Beck]] [[Category:Films shot in New York (state)]] [[Category:Teenage pregnancy in film]]

{{otheruses}} A '''thought leader''' is an individual or firm that is recognized as an authority in a specialized field and whose expertise is sought and often rewarded.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/russprince/2012/03/16/what-is-a-thought-leader/ |title=What Is A Thought Leader? |publisher=Forbes |date=2012-03-16 |accessdate=2014-02-15}}</ref> The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' gives as its first citation for the phrase an 1887 description of [[Henry Ward Beecher]] as "one of the great thought-leaders in America." The term had earlier (1876) been applied to [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]], who was said to manifest "the wizard power of a thought-leader."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QbgnAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA38&dq=%22thought+leader%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiyg7X_lv7aAhVqxVQKHZWVAIkQ6AEIUzAI#v=onepage&q=%22thought%20leader%22&f=false|title=The Theistic Annual for 1876|date=1876|page=38|accessdate=2018-05-11}}</ref>
In a 1990 article in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' Marketing section, Patrick Reilly used the term "thought leader publications" to refer to such magazines as ''[[Harper's]]''. <ref>Patrick Reilly, "'Thought' Magazines Weather Ad Storms." Wall Street Journal, Nov. 9, 1990.</ref> In the previous decade the term was revived and reengineered by marketers to emphasize an intangible quality of products and brands.
The term is sometimes used to characterize leaders of [[service club]]s, officers of [[veteran]]s' organizations, of [[civic organization]]s, of [[women's club]]s, lodges, regional officials and insurance [[executive (management)|executive]]s.<ref>[[Carey McWilliams (journalist)|Carey McWilliams]] (1951) "Government by Whitaker and Baxter II", [[The Nation]], page 367, April 21</ref><ref>[[Scott Cutlip]] (1994) ''The Unseen Power'', page 607</ref>
==Meanings== ===Public sphere=== Despite being conceived as a laudatory description, the idea of thought leadership is seen to be inherently contradictory. Since the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] thinking has been taken to an autonomous activity, relying on [[logic]] and not on external [[authority]]. [[Max Weber]] noted in his studies on [[vocation]] that scholars and experts are not necessarily good leaders.<ref>Weber, Max (2004). [[Science as a Vocation]], in ''The Vocation Lectures'', tr. by Rodney LIvingstone, and Edited by David Owen and Tracy Strong (Illinois: Hackett Books).</ref> Recently (2017) political scientist [[Daniel W. Drezner]] contrasted the thought leader to the public intellectual. According to his view intellectuals cultivate opposing views and ambiguities while thought leaders "develop their own singular lens to explain the world, and then proselytize that worldview to anyone within earshot".<ref>Drezner, Daniel W. (2017). ''The Ideas Industry: How Pessimists, Partisans, and Plutocrats are Transforming the Marketplace of Ideas''. Oxford: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|9780190264604}}.</ref>
===Business and marketing=== In business and marketing 'thought leadership' usually refers to a potentially winning [[strategy]]. It is seen as a way of increasing or creating demand for a product or service. High tech firms often publish [[white paper]]s with analyses of the economic benefits of their products as a form of [[marketing]]. These are distinct from technical white papers. [[Consulting firm]]s frequently publish house reports, e.g. The [[McKinsey]] Quarterly,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/insights/mckinsey_quarterly |title=McKinsey Quarterly | McKinsey & Company |publisher=Mckinsey.com |date=2013-10-06 |accessdate=2014-02-15}}</ref> A.T. Kearney Executive Agenda,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.atkearney.com/executive-agenda |title=Executive Agenda ® - A.T. Kearney |publisher=Atkearney.com |date=2011-03-11 |accessdate=2014-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219210420/http://www.atkearney.com/executive-agenda |archivedate=2014-02-19 |df= }}</ref> [[Strategy&]]'s Strategy and Business,<ref>{{cite web|last=Ludwig |first=Helmuth |url=http://www.strategy-business.com/ |title=strategy+business: international business strategy news articles and award-winning analysis |publisher=Strategy-business.com |date=2014-02-11 |accessdate=2014-02-15}}</ref> or [[Deloitte]] Review<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/misc/litetopicpage.MF-US-Tags.deloitte-review.html |title=Deloitte Review - A semiannual publication for business leaders |publisher=Deloitte.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-15}}</ref> where they publish the results of research, new management models and examples of the use of consulting methodologies.<ref>http://www.eclicktick.com/AgileDemandCreation.docx</ref>
Specialist agencies now exist to help corporate clients create evidence-based thought leadership, such as [https://www.delineate.agency Delineate], [[Longitude Research|Longitude]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ig.ft.com/ft-1000/|title=The FT 1000: Europe’s fastest-growing companies|website=ig.ft.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-05-16}}</ref> and others. In addition, major publishing brands also offer similar services, such as the EIU, Forbes and Wall Street Journal.
==Criticism of the phrase and concept== The phrase "thought leader" is identified by some writers as an annoying example of [[business jargon]],<ref>Wendy Webb, [http://www.nfib.com/content/resources/start-a-business/attention-thought-leaders-and-evangelists-your-business-jargon-is-annoying-71825/ Attention Thought Leaders and Evangelists: Your Business Jargon Is Annoying], [[National Federation of Independent Business]] (December 3, 2015).</ref> and appeared in ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine's 2013 annual "tournament" of "corporate America’s most insufferable" business [[buzzword]]s and [[cliché]]s.<ref>Brett Nelson, [https://www.forbes.com/sites/brettnelson/2013/02/05/business-jargon-bracketology-which-annoying-corporate-buzzword-cliche-or-euphemism-will-win-forbes-ncaa-style-tourney-vote-now/#2e976e097227 Business Jargon Bracketology: Which Annoying Corporate Buzzword, Cliché Or Euphemism Will Win Forbes' NCAA-Style Tourney? Vote Now!], ''Forbes'' (February 5, 2015).</ref> Kevin Money and Nuno Da Camara of the John Madejski Centre for Reputation at the [[University of Reading]]'s [[Henley Management College]] write that the nebulous nature of the phrase (the unclear nature of "what is and what is not thought leadership") contributes to its reputation among cynics as "meaningless management speak."<ref>Kevin Money & Nuno Da Camara, [https://next.ft.com/content/d9ec82ea-9f67-11dc-8031-0000779fd2ac Comment: Is thought leadership a cutting edge strategy or meaningless management speak?], ''Financial Times'' (December 2, 2007).</ref> Some writers, such as ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'' contributor Dorie Clark, have defended the phrase, while agreeing "that it is very icky when people call themselves thought leaders because that sounds a little bit egomaniacal."<ref>[https://hbr.org/ideacast/2015/10/why-the-term-thought-leader-isnt-gross.html Why the Term "Thought Leader" Isn't Gross], ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'' ''Ideacast'' (Dorie Clark interview by Sarah Green Carmichael) (October 1, 2015).</ref>
''[[New York Times]]'' columnist [[David Brooks (journalist)|David Brooks]] mocked the lifecycle of the role in a satirical column entitled "The Thought Leader," published in December 2013.<ref>David Brooks, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/17/opinion/brooks-the-thought-leader.html The Thought Leader]", ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 17, 2013.</ref>
A [[parody]] on the term was published in 2016 of Chris Kelly on Canadian television's ''This is That'' program. In the process of the discussion, imitating TED talks, Kelly elicits responses from the audience that exemplify the effect he describes as the result of applying well-known marketing techniques to achieve the impression of being an erudite speaker.<ref>http://www.avclub.com/article/deconstruction-all-ted-talks-itself-ideal-ted-talk-238070</ref>
== See also == {{wiktionary}} * [[TLG index of thought leaders]] * [[Opinion leadership]] * [[Creative class]] * [[Futures studies]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * Brosseau, Denise (2014), [https://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1118647610,descCd-buy.html Ready to Be a Thought Leader?] (Wiley/Jossey-Bass) *Karin Frick, Detlef Guertler, Peter A. Gloor, (2013), ''Coolhunting for the World's Thought Leaders'', Presented at COINs13 Conference, Chile, 2013 [[arxiv:1308.1160|arXiv]] * {{cite news |last=Acharya |first=Nupur |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303936704576397170403905388?mod=googlewsj |title=Infosys, Tata Brands Beat Google and Apple |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=2011-06-20 |accessdate=2012-01-11}} * Myslewski, Rik (November 25, 2009). [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/11/25/thought_leadership/ "Apple tops Google as UK 'Thought Leader'{{-"}}]. ''[[The Register]]''.
[[Category:Neologisms]] [[Category:Systems thinking]]

{{Main|Aphasia}} '''Transcortical motor aphasia''' ('''TMoA'''), also known as '''commissural dysphasia''' or '''white matter dysphasia''', results from damage in the anterior superior [[frontal lobe]] of the language-dominant hemisphere. This damage is typically due to [[cerebrovascular accident]] (CVA). TMoA is generally characterized by reduced speech output, which is a result of dysfunction of the affected region of the brain.<ref name=":2" /> The left hemisphere is usually responsible for performing language functions, although left-handed individuals have been shown to perform language functions using either their left or right hemisphere depending on the individual. The anterior frontal lobes of the language-dominant hemisphere are essential for initiating and maintaining speech.<ref name=":2" /> Because of this, individuals with TMoA often present with difficulty in speech maintenance and initiation.
Damage in the [[Watershed area (medical)|watershed region]] does not directly harm the areas of the brain involved in [[language production]] or [[sentence processing|comprehension]]; instead, the damage isolates these areas from the rest of the brain.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = Introduction to Neurogenic Communication Disorders|last = Brookshire|first = R. H.|publisher = Mosby|year = 2007|isbn = |location = St. Louis, MO|pages = }}</ref> If there is damage to the frontal lobe, [[executive functions]] related to language use are often affected. Executive functions relevant to language include activating language responses, controlling syntax (grammar), and narrative discourse. Difficulties in these areas can lead to supplementary deficits involving difficulties forming complex sentences, choosing which words to use appropriately, and initiating speech in conversation.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = A specific pattern of executive dysfunctions in transcortical motor aphasia|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/02687038.2013.835783|journal = Aphasiology|date = 2013-12-01|issn = 0268-7038|pages = 1426–1439|volume = 27|issue = 12|doi = 10.1080/02687038.2013.835783|first = Lilla|last = Zakariás|first2 = Attila|last2 = Keresztes|first3 = Gyula|last3 = Demeter|first4 = Ágnes|last4 = Lukács}}</ref>
The extent and location of the brain damage will impact the degree and variety of language functioning characteristics (i.e. damage deep to the frontal lobe and/or damage across multiple regions will greatly impair language). Right [[hemiparesis]], or right-sided paralysis, may coincide with TMoA if the lesion in the anterior frontal lobe is large enough and extends into the posterior frontal lobe.<ref name=":2" />
There are some other forms of aphasia that relate to TMoA. For instance, adynamic aphasia is a form of TMoA that is characterized by sparse speech. This occurs as a result of executive functioning in the frontal lobe.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gold|title=Adynamic Aphasia: A Transcortical Motor Aphasia with Defective Semantic Strategy Information|journal=Brain and Language|date=1997|volume=3|issue=57|pages=374–393|doi=10.1006/brln.1997.1750|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Another form of aphasia related to TMoA is dynamic aphasia. Patients with this form of aphasia may present with a contiguity disorder in which they have difficulty combining linguistic elements. For dynamic aphasia, this is most apparent when the patient is asked to sequence at the sentence level whereas for other aphasias contiguity disorder can be seen at the phoneme or word level.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=PhD|first=Alfredo Ardila|date=2010-03-01|title=A proposed reinterpretation and reclassification of aphasic syndromes|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/02687030802553704|journal=Aphasiology|volume=24|issue=3|pages=363–394|doi=10.1080/02687030802553704|issn=0268-7038}}</ref>
==Characteristics== TMoA is classified as a non-fluent aphasia that is characterized by a significantly reduced output of speech, but good auditory comprehension.<ref name=":2" /> Auditory comprehension skills remain intact because the [[arcuate fasciculus]] and [[Wernicke's area|Wernicke's]] area are not impaired.<ref name=":2" /> Individuals with TMoA also exhibit good repetition skills and can repeat long, complex phrases effortlessly and without error.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://schatz.sju.edu/neuro/aphasia/tma.html|title=Transcortical motor aphasia}}</ref> However, spontaneous speech often presents with [[paraphasia]]s (a term used to describe a wide variety of speech errors that are caused by aphasia). Regardless of any relative communication strengths, individuals with TMoA are typically poor conversational partners.<ref name=":2" /> Due to damage in the anterior superior [[frontal lobe]], people with TMoA have deficits in initiation and maintenance of conversations, which results in reduced speech output.<ref name=":2" /> A person with TMoA may seldomly produce utterances and typically remain silent.<ref name=":2" /> The utterances that they do produce are typically only one to two words long. However, in more structured and predictable interactions, individuals with TMoA tend to respond more fluently and promptly.<ref name=":2" /> In addition, these individuals are characterized by their attentiveness and cooperation and are often described as being task-oriented.<ref name=":2" />
== Causes == Neurological imaging has shown that TMoA is typically caused by an [[Infarction|infarct]] of the anterior superior frontal lobe in the [[Lateral sulcus|perisylvian]] area<ref name=":6">{{cite journal | author = Ardila A | year = 2017 | title = Some rare neuropsychological syndromes: Central achromatopsia, Bálint's syndrome, pure word-deafness, supplementary motor area aphasia | url = | journal = Psychology & Neuroscience | volume = 10 | issue = 3| pages = 314–324 | doi = 10.1037/pne0000093 }}</ref> of the left, or language-dominant, hemisphere.<ref name=":2" /> The anterior superior frontal lobe is known as the prefrontal cortex which is responsible for the initiation and ideation of verbal speech.<ref name="pmid15647494">{{cite journal | vauthors = Tanaka S, Honda M, Sadato N | title = Modality-specific cognitive function of medial and lateral human Brodmann area 6 | journal = J. Neurosci. | volume = 25 | issue = 2 | pages = 496–501 | date = January 2005 | pmid = 15647494 | doi = 10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4324-04.2005 }}</ref> The damage leaves the major language networks, [[Broca's area|Broca’s]] and [[Wernicke's area|Wernicke’]]<nowiki/>s areas and the [[Arcuate fasciculus|arcuate fasiculus]], unaffected.<ref name=":2" /> Brain injury can result from a stroke caused by left [[anterior cerebral artery]] (ACA) occlusion,<ref name=":6" /> [[brain tumor]]s, [[traumatic brain injury]] (TBI), or progressive neurological disorders.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.asha.org/PRPSpecificTopic.aspx?folderid=8589934663&section=Assessment|title=Aphasia: Assessment|author=<!--Not stated--> |year=2017|website=American-Speech-Language-Hearing Association|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=October 22, 2018}}</ref>
== Diagnosis == TMoA is diagnosed by the referring physician and [[Speech-language pathology|speech-language pathologist]] (SLP). The overall sign of TMoA is nonfluent, reduced, fragmentary echoic, and perseverative speech with frequent hesitations and pauses.<ref name=":4" /> Patients with TMoA also have difficulty initiating and maintaining speech.<ref name=":2" /> However, speech articulation and auditory comprehension remain typical.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Freedman|first=M.|last2=Alexander|date=1984|others=Naeser|title=Anatomic Basis of transcortical motor aphasia|url=|journal=Neurology|volume=34|pages=409–417|via=|doi=10.1212/wnl.34.4.409}}</ref> The hallmark sign of TMoA is intact repetition in the presence of these signs and symptoms.<ref name=":5" />
TMoA, or any other type of aphasia, is identified and diagnosed through the screening and assessment process. Screening can be conducted by a SLP or other professional when there is a suspected aphasia.<ref name=":3" /> The screening does not diagnose aphasia, rather it points to the need for a further comprehensive assessment. A screening typically includes evaluation of oral motor functions, speech production skills, comprehension, use of written and verbal language, cognitive communication, swallowing, and hearing.<ref name=":3" /> Both the screening and assessment must be sensitive to the patient’s linguistic and cultural differences.<ref name=":3" /> An individual will be recommended to receive a comprehensive assessment if their screening shows signs of aphasia. Under the [[American Speech–Language–Hearing Association|American Speech-Language-Hearing Association]] (ASHA) and [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) guidelines and the ''[[International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health]]'' (ICF) framework, the comprehensive assessment encompasses not only speech and language, but also impairments in body structure and function, co-morbid deficits, limitations in activity and participation, and contextual (environmental and personal) factors.<ref name=":3" /> The assessment can be static (current functioning) or dynamic (ongoing) and the assessment tools can be standardized or nonstandardized.<ref name=":3" /> Typically, the assessment for aphasia includes a gathering of a case history, a self-report from the patient, an oral-motor examination, assessment of expressive and receptive language in spoken and written forms, and identification of facilitators and barriers to patient success.<ref name=":3" /> From this assessment, the SLP will determine type of aphasia and the patient's communicative strengths and weaknesses and how their diagnosis may impact their overall quality of life.<ref name=":3" />
== Treatment == Treatment for all types of aphasia, including transcortical motor aphasia, is usually provided by a [[Speech-language pathology|speech-language pathologist]]. The SLP chooses specific therapy tasks and goals based on the speech and language abilities and needs of the individual.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.asha.org/public/speech/disorders/Aphasia/|title=Aphasia|last=American Speech Language Hearing Association|first=|date=|website=asha.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-13}}</ref> In general for individuals with TMoA, treatment should capitalize on their strong auditory comprehension and repetition skills and address the individual's reduced speech output and difficulty initiating and maintaining a conversation.<ref name=":2" /> New research in aphasia treatment is showing the benefit of the Life Participation Approach to Aphasia (LPAA) in which goals are written based on the skills needed by the individual patient to participate in specific real-life situations (i.e. communicating effectively with nurses or gaining employment).<ref>{{cite book|title=Section III: Psychosocial/Functional Approaches to Intervention: Focus on Improving Ability to Perform Communication Activities of Daily Living|last1=Chapey|first1=Roberta|last2=Duchan|first2=Judith|last3=Elman|first3=Roberta|last4=Garcia|first4=Linda|last5=Kagan|first5=Aura|last6=Lyon|first6=Jon|last7=Simmons-Mackie|first7=Nina|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=279–289|chapter=Life-Participation Approach to Aphasia: A Statement of Values for the Future}}</ref> Based on the specific needs of the patient, SLPs can provide a variety of treatment activities.
To improve word retrieval and initiation difficulties, clinicians may use confrontation naming in which the patient is asked to name various objects and pictures. Depending on the severity, they may also use sentence completion tasks in which the clinician says sentences with the final word(s) missing and expects the patient to fill in the blank.<ref name=":2" /> Limited research suggests that nonsymbolic limb movement on the left side (i.e. tapping the left hand on the table) during sentence production can increase verbal initiations. The use of the left arm in left space stimulates initiation mechanisms in the right hemisphere of the brain which can also be used for language allowing individuals to produce more grammatical sentences with higher fluency and more verbal initiation.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors = Raymer AM, Rowland L, Haley M, Crosson, B|first=|date=2002|title=Nonsymbolic movement training to improve sentence generation in transcortical motor aphasia: A case study.|journal=Aphasiology|volume=16 |issue=4–6|pages=493–506|doi=10.1080/02687030244000239}}</ref>
To increase speech output, the clinician may provide a set of pictures and prompt the patient to describe or elaborate on the events pictured. The clinician can also provide spoken or written words and prompt the patient to use the words in a sentence.<ref name=":2" /> Additionally, the clinician can ask questions based on the patient’s experiences, opinions, or general knowledge and prompt the patient to answer with phrases or sentences. To work on more connected speech, the clinician may ask the patient to describe procedures such as making a sandwich or doing laundry.<ref name=":2" /> A study found that syntax training in which sentence constructions are elicited on a hierarchy of difficulty produced gains in grammatically complete utterances and utterances that successfully communicated novel and accurate information.<ref name="pmid11322572">{{cite journal | vauthors = Murray LL, Heather Ray A | title = A comparison of relaxation training and syntax stimulation for chronic nonfluent aphasia | journal = J Commun Disord | volume = 34 | issue = 1-2 | pages = 87–113 | date = 2001 | pmid = 11322572 | doi = 10.1016/s0021-9924(00)00043-5}}</ref>
To improve conversational skills, SLPs may engage the patient in structured conversations in which supports are provided to help the patient take appropriate conversational turns, maintain the topic of conversation, and formulate appropriate sentences.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2014|title=Rehabilitation of poststroke cognition|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/837792_3|journal=Medscape|volume=34|issue=5|pages=496–503|vauthors=Shigaki CL, Frey SH, Barrett AM}}</ref> Clinicians often need to provide pragmatic guidelines so that the patient’s responses go beyond the clinician’s request and so the clinician does not do the majority of the talking.<ref name=":2" /> Research shows that conversation therapy can improve percent of complex utterances, the efficiency of the utterances for expressing ideas, and total time spent talking over more traditional stimulation therapy.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Savage|first1=Meghan|last2=Donovan|first2=Neila|title=Comparing linguistic complexity and efficieny in conversatino stimulation and conversation therapy in aphasia|journal=International Journal Language and Communication Disorders|date=January 2017|volume=52|issue=1|pages=21–29|doi=10.1111/1460-6984.12252}}</ref>
In order to improve the patient’s abilities to functionally communicate in their natural settings, the SLP will provide strategies and techniques to enhance their success in communicative settings (i.e. supplementing speech with nonverbal communication).<ref name=":2" /> Research supports the use of reduced syntax therapy to help patients overcome the non-fluent speech and agrammatism that often occurs with TMoA. Because [[agrammatism]] inhibits the patient's ability to form grammatically correct sentences, this type of treatment involves reducing these agrammatic deficits and teaching the patient to simplify linguistic structures while still conveying the message in order for language used to be more productive in conversation.<ref name="Ruiter, M.B. 2010">{{cite journal|year=2010|title=Speaking in ellipses: the effect of a compensatory style of speech on functional communication in chronic agrammatism|url=|journal=Neuropsychological Rehabilitation|volume=20|issue=3|pages=423–58|doi=10.1080/09602010903399287|pmid=20155573|vauthors=Ruiter MB, Kolk HH, Rietveld TC}}</ref>
Additionally, they may train the patient’s communication partners to support the conversational abilities of the patient by facilitating the use of preserved cognitive and social functions. Research supports the use of various partner training programs such as Supported Conversation for Adults with Aphasia from the Aphasia Institute.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kagan|first1=Aura|last2=Black|first2=Sandra|last3=Duchan|first3=Judith|last4=Simmons-Mackie|first4=Nina|last5=Square|first5=Paula|title=Training Volunteers as Conversation Partners Using "Supported Conversation for Adults with Aphasia" (SCA): A Controlled Trial|journal=Journal of Speech, Language and Hearing Research|date=June 2001|volume=44|pages=624–638|doi=10.1044/1092-4388(2001/051)}}</ref> In this program, the focus is put on acknowledging the patient’s competence and helping them to reveal that competence. Strategies include saying “I know you know” when appropriate, using gestures to supplement messages, limiting background noise, and given sufficient time for response.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Aphasia Institute|title=Communication Tools: Communicative Access & SCA|url=https://www.aphasia.ca/communicative-access-sca/|website=aphasia.ca|accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>
From a neuroscience perspective, research has found that a [[dopamine agonist]], [[bromocriptine]], taken by mouth, has provided positive outcomes during intervention for non-fluent types of aphasia, such as TMoA or adynamic aphasia.<ref name=":7">{{cite journal|year=2008|title=Aphasia therapy on a neuroscience basis|url=|journal=Aphasiology|volume=22|issue=6|pages=563–599|doi=10.1080/02687030701612213|pmc=2557073|pmid=18923644|vauthors=Pulvemüller F, Bethier ML}}</ref> Studies have found that bromocriptine increased neural networks which assist with the initiation of speech in individuals who possess non-fluent characteristics of speech.<ref>{{cite journal|displayauthors=etal|year=1991|title=Transcortical aphasia: Importance of the nonspeech dominant hemisphere in language repetition|journal=Brain|volume=114|issue=3|pages=1409–1427|doi=10.1093/brain/114.3.1409|vauthors=Berthier ML, Starkstein SE, Leiguarda R, Ruiz A, Mayberg HS, Wagner H}}</ref>
In order to capitalize on [[neuroplasticity]] for treatment of all types of aphasia, timing, intensity, duration, and repetition of treatment should be taken into consideration. Research has found that aphasia treatment initiated during the earlier acute post-injury phase is more effective compared to treatment initiated in the chronic phase.<ref name=":8">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kleim JA, Jones TA | title = Principles of experience-dependent neural plasticity: implications for rehabilitation after brain damage | journal = J. Speech Lang. Hear. Res. | volume = 51 | issue = 1 | pages = S225–39 | date = February 2008 | pmid = 18230848 | doi = 10.1044/1092-4388(2008/018) }}</ref> With regard to intensity and duration of treatment, studies reported maximum recovery occurred with intense weekly therapy (approximately 8 hours per week) was delivered over a 2–3 month period.<ref name="pmid12649521">{{cite journal | vauthors = Bhogal SK, Teasell R, Speechley M | title = Intensity of aphasia therapy, impact on recovery | journal = Stroke | volume = 34 | issue = 4 | pages = 987–93 | date = April 2003 | pmid = 12649521 | doi = 10.1161/01.STR.0000062343.64383.D0 }}</ref> Other research shows that distributed therapy may be more beneficial than high intensity therapy.<ref name="pmid26106114">{{cite journal | vauthors = Dignam J, Copland D, McKinnon E, Burfein P, O'Brien K, Farrell A, Rodriguez AD | title = Intensive Versus Distributed Aphasia Therapy: A Nonrandomized, Parallel-Group, Dosage-Controlled Study | journal = Stroke | volume = 46 | issue = 8 | pages = 2206–11 | date = August 2015 | pmid = 26106114 | doi = 10.1161/STROKEAHA.115.009522 }}</ref> More research is needed to determine which is best, but it may be found that the ideal duration and intensity of therapy is variable depending on the patient and their needs.
== Prognosis == In relation to other types of aphasia, TMoA occurs less frequently, so there is less information on its prognosis.<ref name=":2" /> In general, for individuals with aphasia, most recovery is seen within 6 months of the stroke or injury although more recovery may continue in the following months or years.<ref name=":2" /> The timeline of recovery may look different depending on the type of stroke that caused the aphasia. With an ischemic stroke, recovery is greatest within the first two weeks and then diminishes overtime until the progress stabilizes. With a hemorrhagic stroke, the patient often shows little improvement in the first few weeks and then has relatively rapid recovery until they stabilize.<ref name=":2" />
In a study involving eight patients with border zone lesions, all patients presented with transcortical mixed aphasia initially after the stroke. Three of these patients made a complete recovery within a few days post-stroke. For three other patients with more anterior lesions, their aphasia transitioned to TMoA. All participants in the study regained full language abilities within 18 months following their stroke.<ref name="pmid21554494">{{cite journal | vauthors = Flamand-Roze C, Cauquil-Michon C, Roze E, Souillard-Scemama R, Maintigneux L, Ducreux D, Adams D, Denier C | title = Aphasia in border-zone infarcts has a specific initial pattern and good long-term prognosis | journal = Eur. J. Neurol. | volume = 18 | issue = 12 | pages = 1397–401 | date = December 2011 | pmid = 21554494 |issn = 1468-1331| doi = 10.1111/j.1468-1331.2011.03422.x }}</ref> This suggests a positive long-term prognosis for patients with TMoA. However, this might not be the case for all patients and more research is needed in order to solidify these findings. Another study found that prognosis of TMoA is affected by lesion size. Smaller lesions typically cause delays in speech initiation; whereas, larger lesions lead to more profound language abnormalities and difficulty with abstract language abilities.<ref name=":5" />
Research has shown that treatment has a direct effect on aphasia outcomes.<ref name="pmid22063820">{{cite journal | vauthors = Basso A, Macis M | title = Therapy efficacy in chronic aphasia | journal = Behav Neurol | volume = 24 | issue = 4 | pages = 317–25 | date = 2011 | pmid = 22063820 | pmc = 5377972 | doi = 10.3233/BEN-2011-0342 }}</ref> Intensity, duration and timing of treatment all need to be taken in to consideration when choosing a course of treatment and determining a prognosis. In general, greater intensity leads to greater improvement.<ref name="pmid18230850">{{cite journal | vauthors = Raymer AM, Beeson P, Holland A, Kendall D, Maher LM, Martin N, Murray L, Rose M, Thompson CK, Turkstra L, Altmann L, Boyle M, Conway T, Hula W, Kearns K, Rapp B, Simmons-Mackie N, Gonzalez Rothi LJ |display-authors = 6| title = Translational research in aphasia: from neuroscience to neurorehabilitation | journal = J. Speech Lang. Hear. Res. | volume = 51 | issue = 1 | pages = S259–75 | date = February 2008 | pmid = 18230850 | doi = 10.1044/1092-4388(2008/020) }}</ref> For duration, longer-term treatment produces more permanent changes.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Bayles|first=Kathryn|last2=Tomoeda|first2=Cheryl|date=November 2010|title=Neuroplasticity: Implications for Treating Cognitive-Communication Disorders|url=|journal=ASHA Convention|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> As for timing, beginning treatment too early may be difficult for the system which has not recovered enough to do intensive therapy, but beginning too late may result missing the window of the opportunity in which the most change can occur.<ref name=":9" /> [[Neuroplasticity]], the brain's natural ability to reorganize itself following a traumatic event, occurs best when treatment connects simultaneous events, maintains attention, taps into positive emotion, utilizes repetition tasks, and is specific to the individual's needs.<ref name=":9" />
Other factors affecting prognosis includes location and site of [[lesion]]. Since the lesion that results in TMoA usually occurs in the watershed area and does not directly involve the areas of the brain responsible for general language abilities, prognosis for these patients is good overall.<ref name=":2" /> Other factors that determine a patient’s prognosis include age, education prior to the stroke, gender, motivation, and support.<ref name="pmid11001162">{{cite journal | vauthors = Thompson CK | title = Neuroplasticity: evidence from aphasia | journal = J Commun Disord | volume = 33 | issue = 4 | pages = 357–66 | date = 2000 | pmid = 11001162 | pmc = 3086401 }}</ref>
